reporting-org.narrative: European Centre for Development Policy Management (ECDPM)

title.narrative: 8. Institutions, Markets and Regional Integration

description.narrative: The key ECDPM impact areas that this work stream refers to are a) legitimate and accountable state institutions and engaged societies, and b) sustainable economic transformation with shared prosperity. This is to be principally achieved through work to better inform actors (outcome i) , and thus help reduce the policy implementation gap (outcome iv), though other impact areas also seem relevant. The change sought is that African policies and donor support for continental, regional and integration national policy reforms efforts explicitly build-in and build on an understanding of, and process-driven approach to political economic realities (relating to institutions, incentives, power) and how these influence policy design, implementation and impact. Specific changes relate to bringing a political-economy view to how different actors engage around continental and regional integration policies, including corridor development in West, Southern and East Africa as a means to promote agriculture, trade and industrialisation.This work will also feed into debates around development policy more generally, the need for this to be politically informed , and what this means in practice (building on the five As approach) including at the national level. Where possible this will also imply further developing ECDPM’s analytical tools for PEA.

Biennial outcome narrative by ECDPM assessing the progress made towards the envisaged outcomes in the period: 2017-01-01 - 2018-06-30

title.narrative: Qualitative indicator

comment.narrative: ECDPM reports biennially on its outcomes in a narrative

Regional Organisations in Africa - partnerships for effective integration Building on the past work of political economy of regional integration in the African Union and five of its Regional Economic Communities (PERIA) from 2015-2016, this workstream has expanded the work on regional organisations to 11 more regional organisations around some sector specific challenges. The aim of the work is to analyse what drives or blocks effective change in key areas of regional and cross-country cooperation. Though commissioned by an important donor to regional organisations (BMZ/GIZ), the findings are targeted at both donors and, importantly, African stakeholders working with or for regional organisations. 31 reports on specific topics in different regions have been finalised and communicated broadly since 2017, offering a basis for further dialogue with donors and stakeholders alike. Responses to these reports, from international development partners in particular, has led to further analysis on regional industrialisation strategies, peace and security, regional water challenges, regional power pools, and the aid architecture itself at a time that the African Union has initiated a new round of ambitious institutional reforms. The approach in these follow-on invitations is to contribute to more inclusive dialogue processes by informed stakeholders around strengthening African regional institutions for effective development. Examples include providing inputs to conferences on ‘rethinking regional integration’ hosted by the African Economic Research Council, inputs to the community of practice on ‘thinking and working politically’ at a regional level, as well as providing inputs to conferences between donors such as the UNDP for their approach to Central African regional organisations. Requests are increasingly arriving from other donors such as the World Bank, interested in informing their work with river basin organisations and Southern African Development Community (SADC), and organisations such as SADC for inputs into strategic dialogue among key stakeholders in the region on “the SADC we want”. The above requests show demand to use the analysis to feed ongoing regional organisations’ reform strategies and policies. So far in the process, the first outputs have provided insights on “the reality on the ground” that help guide future research for ECDPM and others, and by better informing international partners, will help contribute to more effective multi-actor partnerships (African Union and partnerships with donors) and capacitated actors (Mali and regional water challenges). Other public outputs include a map tool to illustrate (and highlight) the overlapping membership of most African countries and regional organisations - shedding light on a key element of discussions around African regionalism. Regional economic integration dynamics A second strand of work takes regional economic dynamics as the entry point, where regional organisations are one of many key actors. In this context the World Bank (WB) also asked the Centre to critically assess the political economy dimensions of regional and cross-country cooperation on SADC and EAC industrialisation, to inform their future support to implementation of their respective regional industrialisation strategies. Such diagnostics provide inputs for informing the WB’s dialogue with its partners on coherent future programming and effective engagement strategies both within the framework of SADC and beyond. The bottom-line of the study was to share evidence on why there is cross-country or regional traction in particular economic sectors and dynamics, and where there is endogenous agency for support to economic transformation. This is now feeding ongoing discussions with the SADC Secretariat about what is feasible and desirable for support at the regional level. In West Africa, the Centre’s political economy analyses of regional economic dynamics around regional value chains (including cement, but also agricultural value chains) and linkages with transport corridors and transport reforms have proven to be most relevant in supporting efforts by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs to advance innovative approaches to linking regional integration support to the transport sector, with envisaged impact on poverty reduction and gender related challenges. Political economy inputs from our analysis have had a strong impact on the design of a new programme that also combines efforts with the EU and USAID to improve donor coordination. Though part of a longer term process - with a strong component of strengthening African organisational and institutional capabilities for facilitation and functional regional cooperation - already the current outputs and influence on programme design point to the potential value of our work in contributing to such economic transformation outcomes while ECDPM continues to be invited to discuss and engage in the ongoing process. Tool development and applied political economy analysis The Centre is an active member of the Community of Practice on Thinking and Working Politically in order to develop the tools, acquire the capabilities and transfer the knowledge to improve the dimensions of power and politics in aid and international relations. Improved context and sector analysis - based on a political economy analytical framework - should underpin politically informed development practice and engagement strategies by external practitioners in order to make partnerships between domestic and regional stakeholders in Africa and their external supporters developmentally effective. Its reputation and its practice with tool development and political economy analyses at regional, sector and national level have convinced the EU Delegation in Tunis to reward a multi-purpose contract to ECDPM. Envisaged intermediary outcomes include transfer of political economy analytical skills with the EUD, better informed dialogue with key actors in Tunisia on identified sectors or development challenges, and sector diagnostics for technically feasible and politically realistic programming by the EUD. Similar initiatives are on-going in parallel with political economy analysis work in Mali, mentioned above. Gender When developing activities the team assesses the gender related challenges - in as far as data, diagnostics and access to information are available - to identify if particular activities can be undertaken within the realm of the Centre in support of empowering women or supporting a more just gender balance. The broad nature of the work, looking at regional organisations, has offered limited opportunities thus far for explicitly addressing the gender dimension.
